questions.question: They serve God well who serve His children.
questions.description: Here the adjective clause ‘who serve His children’ modifies the noun God.

questions.question: Quarrels won’t last long if the fault is only on one side.
questions.description: Here the subordinate adverb clause ‘if the fault is only on one side’ modifies the verb ‘last long’.

questions.question: That you should say so surprises me.
questions.description: A noun clause can be the subject of a verb. Here the noun clause ‘that you should say so’ is the subject of the verb ‘surprises’.

questions.question: Your statement that you found the money in the closet cannot be believed.
questions.description: Here the noun clause ‘that you found the money in the closet’ is in apposition to the noun ‘statement’. Only noun clauses can be used like this.

questions.question: I asked the boy how old he was.
questions.description: Here the noun clause ‘how old he was’ is the object of the verb asked.

questions.question: Uneasy lies the head that wears the crown.
questions.description: Here the adjective clause ‘that wears the crown’ modifies the noun head. Adjective clauses modify nouns and give additional information about them.

questions.question: Youth is the time when the seeds of character are sown.
questions.description: Here the adjective clause when the seeds of character are sown modifies the noun time.

questions.question: Servants who are honest are trusted.
questions.description: Here the adjective clause ‘who are honest’ modifies the noun servants.

questions.question: Because I like you, I shall help you.
questions.description: An adverb clause of reason expresses the reason for the action mentioned in the main clause.

questions.question: The dog followed the boy wherever he went.
questions.description: Here the adverb clause of place ‘wherever he went’ modifies the verb ‘followed’.

questions.question: If I like it, I will buy it.
questions.description: Adverb clauses of condition are usually introduced by the conjunctions if, whether or unless.

questions.question: They spoke in a low voice so that the child would not wake up.
questions.description: Here the adverb clause ‘so that the child would not wake up’ expresses the purpose of the action mentioned in the main clause.
